Name: Parking, Funerals
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to permissible parking for members of the funeral service profession and persons attending funerals.
Text:
Be it enacted by the Council as follows:


    	Section one. Legislative findings and intent. It is hereby found and declared that members of the funeral service profession are frequently called upon to respond to emergencies or situations which warrant immediate attention during the course of administering their duties. In these instances, many members of the funeral service profession are burdened with the task of locating permissible parking, often delaying their ability to transfer human remains from hospitals, to perform an official function at institutions in the City of New York or to conduct a funeral service at a funeral establishment or a house of worship. It is also hereby found that persons attending funerals frequently encounter difficulty locating permissible parking near the funeral establishment at which they are attending a funeral. 
    	It is furthermore found and declared that current New York City Traffic Rules and Regulations do allow parking exemptions for doctors and dentists and representatives of certain not-for profit organizations but do not provide any exemption for members of the funeral service profession who perform a vital service 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. 
    	�2. Chapter one of title nineteen of the administrative code of the City of New York is hereby amended by adding thereto a new section 19-163.1 to follow section 19-162 and to read as follows:
    	�19-163.1 Permissible parking; for members of the funeral service profession and persons attending funerals houses of worship, funeral establishments, hospitals and institutions. a. Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following words shall be defined as follows:
    	1. "Funeral director" means a person to whom a valid license has been issued to engage in funeral directing.
    	2. "Undertaker" means a person to whom a valid license has been issued to engage in undertaking.
    	3. Embalmer" means a person to whom a valid license has been issued to engage in embalming.
    	4. "Funeral directing" means the care and disposal of the body of a deceased person or the preserving, disinfecting and preparing by embalming or otherwise, the body of a deceased person for funeral services, transportation, burial or cremation.
    	5. "Undertaking" means the care, disposal, transportation, burial or cremation by any means other than embalming of the body of a deceased person.
    	6. "Embalming" means preparing, disinfecting and preserving, either hypodermically, arterially or by any other recognized means  the body of a deceased person for burial, cremation or other final disposition.
    	7. "Funeral establishment" means a single physical location, address or premises devoted to or used for the care and preparation of a body of a deceased person for disposition and for mourning or funeral ceremonial purposes.
    	8. "House of worship" shall mean a building which serves solely as a church, synagogue, temple, mosque or for the purpose of organized religious counseling or prayer on behalf of a religious corporation.
    	9. "Hospital" shall mean a facility engaged principally in providing hospital service by or under the supervision of a physician for the prevention, diagnosis or treatment of human disease, pain, injury, deformity or physical condition, including, but not limited to, a general hospital, nursing home, tuberculosis hospital, chronic disease hospital, maternity hospital, lying-in asylum, sanitarium or other facility engaged principally in providing services for the prevention, diagnosis or treatment of mental disability and such facilities providing hospital service.
    	10. "Hospital Service" shall mean the preadmission, out-patient, in-patient and post discharge care provided in or by a hospital, and such other items or services as are necessary for such care, which are provided by or under the supervision of a physician for the purpose of prevention, diagnosis or treatment of human disease, pain, injury, disability, deformity or physical condition, including, but not limited to, nursing service, service provided by an intern or resident in training, laboratory service, medical social service, drugs, biologicals, supplies, appliances, equipment, bed and board.
    	11. "Institution" shall mean the offices of a federal, state or local governmental agency including, but not limited to, a department of health, the office of the chief medical examiner, a public administrator, an embassy, consulate or mission maintained by a foreign government, an airport or a railroad station.
    	b. Notwithstanding any local law, regulation or rule to the contrary, it shall be permissible for a funeral director, embalmer or undertaker to park a motor vehicle which is owned, operated or hired by such person, and bears an appropriate department of transportation identification card, in an available space upon any street, roadway or place adjacent to the funeral establishment, the house of worship, hospital or institution at which the funeral director, embalmer or undertaker is performing official duties. It shall also be permissible for a person attending a funeral to park a motor vehicle for a period of up to three hours in an available space upon any street, roadway or place adjacent to the funeral establishment at which such person is attending a funeral. However, it shall be unlawful to park a motor vehicle in any manner which obstructs the use of any fire hydrant, designated handicapped parking space, official bus stop, emergency exit, emergency entrance or driveway.
    	c. The commissioner shall make such rules as may be necessary and set such fees as may be appropriate for the issuance of identification cards pursuant to this section.
    	�3. This local law shall take effect immediately.
